revision.text:
[[File:Roman glass round bottom vase 01.11.010.tif|150px|right|thumb|Roman glass vase with a weathered surface showing discoloration, cracking and flaking]] [[Image:Glassdisease.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Bottle with glass disease]]
'''Glass disease''', also referred to as '''sick glass''' or '''glass illness''', is a degradation process of glass that can result in '''weeping''', '''crizzling''', '''spalling''', cracking and fragmentation.<ref name="Swift"/><ref name="Kunicki-Goldfinger">{{cite journal|last1=Kunicki-Goldfinger|first1=Jerzy J.|title=Unstable historic glass: symptoms, causes, mechanisms and conservation|journal=Reviews in Conservation|date=2008|volume=9|pages=47-60 |url=https://www.iiconservation.org/node/2258|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref> Glass disease is caused by an inherent instability in the chemical composition of the original [[glass]] formula.<ref name="Connor"/> Properties of a particular glass will vary with the type and proportions of [[silica]], [[alkali]] and [[Alkaline earth metal|alkaline earth]] in its composition.<ref name="Hogg"/> Once damage has occurred it is irreversible, but decay processes can be slowed by climate control to regulate surrounding temperature, humidity, and air flow.
==Chemical composition and decay== Glass disease is caused by an inherent fault in the chemical composition of the original [[glass]] formula.<ref name="Connor"/> Glass contains three types of components: ''network formers'' establish basic structure, ''network stabilizers'' make glass strong and water resistant, and ''[[Ceramic flux|flux]]'' lowers the melting point at which the glass can be formed.<ref name="Distillations">{{cite journal|last1= Cansler |first1=Clay |title=From Ancient to Art Nouveau |journal=Distillations |date=2017|volume=3|issue=2 |pages=24-25 |url=}}</ref> Common formulations of glass may include [[silica]] (SiO<sub>2</sub>) as a former, alkali oxides such as [[Sodium oxide|soda]] (Na<sub>2</sub>O) or [[potash]] (K<sub>2</sub>O) for flux, and alkaline earth oxides such as [[Lime (material)|lime]] (CaO) for stabilizing.<ref name="Hogg">{{cite journal|last1=Hogg|first1=Simon|last2=McPhail|first2=David|last3=Oakley|first3=Victoria|last4=Rogers|first4=Philip|title=Cracking Crizzling - Eight Years of Collaborative Research|journal=Conservation Journal|date=1998|issue=29|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/journals/conservation-journal/issue-29/cracking-crizzling-eight-years-of-collaborative-research/|accessdate=19 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="Distillations"/>
Structurally, glass is composed of a network of SiO<sub>4</sub>-tetrahedrons. In addition to the ''network former'' silicon which establishes its principal structure, glass contains ''network modifying agents'' such as the alkali ions Na+ and K+ and the alkali earth ions Ca<sub>2</sub>+ and Mg<sub>2</sub>+. Glass does not have a defined [[stoichiometry]], rather the network is flexible. It can incorporate other ions, depending upon factors such as the main composition and firing conditions of the glass.<ref name="Gradmann"/> This causes almost all glass to be chemically unstable to some extent.<ref name="Oakley"/>
Electron charge differences of ions within the structure form the basis of its bonding. Both viscosity and transition temperature are related to the availability of oxygen bonds in the glass's composition. Modifying agents tend to lower the melting point of the silica. Higher contents of SiO<sub>2</sub> increase [[acidity]] of the glass. Higher contents of CaO, Na<sub>2</sub>O, and K<sub>2</sub>O increase [[basicity]].<ref name="Gradmann">{{cite book|last1=Gradmann|first1=Rena|title=Analysis of historical islamic glazes and the development of a substitution|date=2016 |publisher=Julius Maximilian University of Würzburg|location=w|url=https://d-nb.info/1112041508/34|accessdate=20 April 2018}}</ref> The chemical stability of glass decreases when only Na<sub>2</sub>O and K<sub>2</sub>O are added as flux, because bonding becomes weaker. The chemical stability of glass can be increased by adding CaO, MgO, ZnO, and Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>. To be stable, glass composition must balance temperature lowering agents with stabilizing agents.<ref name="Gradmann"/>
Exposure of a glass surface to moisture, either in solution or from humidity in the atmosphere, causes chemical reactions to occur on and below the surface of the glass. The exchange of alkali metal ions (from within the glass) and hydrogen ions (from outside) can cause chemical and structural changes to the glass. When alkali metal cations in the near-surface layer are replaced by smaller hydrogen ions, structural differences between the affected surface layer and the unaffected lower layers of glass cause increasing tensile stress, which in turn can cause cracking.<ref name="Oakley">{{cite journal|last1=Oakley|first1=Victoria|last2=Rogers|first2=Philip |last3=McPhail|first3=David|last4=Amaku|first4=Afi|title=Vessel Glass Deterioration in the Museum Environment: A Quantitative Study by Surface Analysis|journal=Conservation Journal|date=April 1992|issue=3 |url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/journals/conservation-journal/issue-03/vessel-glass-deterioration-in-the-museum-environment-a-quantitative-study-by-surface-analysis/|accessdate=21 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="CW">{{cite journal|title=20 years ago - Investigating crizzling|journal=Chemistry World (originally appeared in ''Chemistry in Britain'', 1992.)|date=3 October 2012|url=https://www.chemistryworld.com/opinion/20-years-ago-investigating-crizzling/5499.article|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref>
The likelihood of degradation due to glass disease depends on the amount and proportion of alkaline compounds mixed with silica, and on surrounding conditions.<ref name="Connor"/> Inadequate [[calcium oxide]] causes the alkalis in the glass to remain water-soluble at a low level of humidity. Exposure to higher levels of [[relative humidity]] during storage or display causes alkali to hydrate and leach out of the glass. Repeated changes in humidity can be particularly damaging. It is important to realize that any glass object can deteriorate if it is exposed to unsuitable environmental conditions.<ref name="O'Hern"/> Crystal, historic glass, or treasured family items should never be exposed to the high temperatures and water pressure of a dishwasher.<ref name="Laidman"/><ref name="VAM">{{cite web|title=Caring for Your Glass|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/c/caring-for-your-glass/|website=Victoria and Albert Museum|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref>
[[Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy|Energy dispersive x-ray analysis]] (EDXA),<ref name="Swift"/><ref name="CW"/> [[scanning electron microscopy]] (SEM) and [[secondary ion mass spectrometry]] (SIMS) can be used to study exchange reactions in different types of glass. By quantifying and studying chemical structure and reactions at the near-surface layer, the mechanisms of glass disease can be better understood.<ref name="Oakley"/> Measurement of the pH of glass surfaces is particularly important if glass objects have a matte surface, or have been exposed to [[kaolin]] or other substances. In the case of extremely small objects such as glass beads, pH measurement may be necessary to determine whether alkaline salts are present and changes in the glass are occurring.<ref name="O'Hern"/><ref name="Lovell"/>
==Stages of deterioration== The processes involved in glass disease can reduce the transparency of the glass or even threaten the integrity of the structure. Glass disease causes a complex disintegration of the glass which can be identified through a variety of symptoms, including weeping, crizzling, spalling, cracking and fragmentation.<ref name="Connor">{{cite news|last1=Connor|first1=Steve|title=Museum tries to stem disease affecting glass: Chemists are being used to combat a disease that is shattering exhibits|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/museum-tries-to-stem-disease-affecting-glass-chemists-are-being-used-to-combat-a-disease-that-is-1556872.html|accessdate=19 April 2018|work=The Independent|date=11 October 1992}}</ref>
===Example=== The following description of glass beads from an object in the collection of the [[British Museum]], effectively illustrates the range of symptoms that can occur with glass disease: {{quote|"Two factors indicated that the deterioration was the result of the phenomenon commonly referred to as ‘glass disease’; first, damage was limited to beads of one particular colour (pale yellow) and second, visible signs of all the various stages of glass disease were present on these beads. This included the presence of small white crystals on the surface of most pale yellow beads and a fine network of uniform cracks or ‘crizzling’ crossing the surface of 55 of the 69 beads. This crizzling appeared to be more prevalent around the bead holes. A total of 32 beads had areas of spalling, or advanced crizzling, where cracks had extended further into the glass structure... Many had areas that had already spalled and the fragments lost. Vertical cracks extending through the glass were present on 37 beads and four beads had become detached due to complete fragmentation."<ref name="Swift"/>}}
===Stage One=== The initial stage of glass disease occurs when moisture causes alkali to be leached out of the glass. This becomes apparent when [[hygroscopic]] alkali deposits on the glass give it a cloudy or hazy appearance.<ref name= "Oakley"/><ref name= "CMOG">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmog.org/article/crizzling |title=Crizzling |author= |date=April 26, 2012 |work= |publisher=Corning Museum of Glass |accessdate=April 26, 2012}}</ref> This may occur within as little as five to 10 years of the glass's manufacturing. The glass may feel slippery or slimy<ref name="Laidman">{{cite news|last1=Laidman|first1=Jenni |title=Seeking cures for glass disease |work=The Blade|url=http://www.toledoblade.com/frontpage/2002/05/13/Seeking-cures-for-glass-disease.html|accessdate=20 April 2018|date=May 13, 2002}}</ref> and tiny droplets, or ''weeping'', may be seen in high humidity (above 55%).<ref name= "Koob"/> The hydrated alkali can form fine crystals on the surface of the glass in low relative humidity (below 40%).<ref name="Hogg"/>
At this stage, it may be possible to gently wash the glass and remove the surface alkali.<ref name= "Koob">{{Cite book |last=Koob |first=Stephen |title=Conservation and Care of Glass Objects |publisher=Archetype Publications |location=New York |year=2006 |isbn=1-904982-08-5}}</ref> This will help to stabilize the glass by reducing the surface pH, and by removing dust, soiling, and hygroscopic components that attract further moisture.<ref name="O'Hern"/>
===Stage Two=== If alkali builds up due to ion exchange, and remains on the surface of the glass, the decay process will accelerate. The presence of sodium or potassium ions in the alkali build up will increase the pH on the surface of the glass, causing it to become basic. This will dissolve silica from the glass as well as releasing more alkali ions.<ref name="Laidman"/><ref name= "Oakley" />
The haziness seen on the glass may not disappear entirely when washed and dried. When examined closely at an angle with a low light, fine cracks like tiny silvery lines or shimmering rays, may be visible.<ref name= "CMOG" /> A microscope can confirm the presence of cracks. The cracks are caused by the loss of alkali, which leaves microscopic gaps in the structure of the glass.<ref name= "Koob" />
===Stage Three=== As higher amounts of alkali leach from the glass cracks are likely to become deeper. ''Crizzling'' is a distinctive network of fine cracks in the glass which is visible to the naked eye.<ref name="Connor"/><ref name="Brill">{{cite journal|last1=Brill|first1=Robert H.|title=Crizzling – a problem in glass conservation|journal=Journal of Glass Studies|date=1975|volume=20|pages=121–131.|url=https://www.cmog.org/sites/default/files/collections/34/348E74A3-0852-4509-8F50-B4BC45EBD363.pdf|accessdate=20 April 2018}}</ref> In some cases, the crazing can gain a more uniform appearance.<ref name= "CMOG" /> However, crizzling may not be uniform due to the creation of micro-climates on the glass.<ref name= "Koob" />
===Stage Four=== Distinct cracks may appear on the surface of the glass, and surface material may flake or chip, a process referred to as ''spalling.''<ref name="Koob" /><ref name= "CMOG" />
===Stage Five===
In the most severe stage of deterioration, the structural integrity of the glass has been lost and the glass may separate into pieces.<ref name= "Koob" />
==Prevalence== A survey of glass objects at the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] in London, in 1992, found that more than 1 in 10 objects in the collection were affected by crizzling, ranging from 16th century Venetian to 20th century Scandinavian glass.<ref name="Connor"/><ref name="Jordan">{{cite journal|last1=Jordan|first1=Fi|last2=Oakley|first2=Victoria|title=In pursuit of a clear answer: An Exhibition Road partnership|journal=Conservation Journal|date=2005|issue=50|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/journals/conservation-journal/issue-50/in-pursuit-of-a-clear-answer-an-exhibition-road-partnership/|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref> Venetian glass is particularly susceptible because artisans minimized the use of lime, to make the glass as clear as possible. The works of modern glassmakers who experiment with their glass formulas, such as [[Ettore Sottsass]], can also be at high risk for damage.<ref name="Laidman"/>
Museums such as the [[National Museum of the American Indian]] may find glass disease an issue of great importance because many of the Native American cultural materials in their collections incorporate [[glass beads]].<ref name="O'Hern">{{cite journal|last1=O'Hern|first1=Robin |last2=McHugh |first2=Kelly |title=Red, Blue, and Wound all over: Evaluating Condition Change and Cleaning of Glass Disease on Beads|journal=Objects Specialty Group Postprints|date=2014|volume=Twenty-One|pages=205-228 |url=http://resources.conservation-us.org/osg-postprints/wp-content/uploads/sites/8/2015/03/osg021-09.pdf|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="McHugh">{{cite journal|last1=Ohern |first1=Robin |last2=McHugh |first2=Kelly |title=Deterioration and Conservation of Unstable Glass Beads on Native American Objects|journal=The Bead Forum|date=2013|volume=63 |url=https://beadresearch.org/wp-content/uploads/Repeating_Material/The_Bead_Forum_Archive/The-Bead-Forum-Issue-63-Autumn-2013.pdf|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref> Small ornamental glass beads were often made cheaply, using recipes with a high flux to silica ratio. This makes them more susceptible to glass disease. Blues, reds, and black are often affected by glass disease. The combination of glass beads with other materials (cordage, fabric, leather, metal, bone, surface colorants, ceremonial substances, and kaolin) complicates deterioration and conservation of ethnographic objects.<ref name="Lovell">{{cite book|last1=Lovell|first1=Adam|title=GLASS BEAD DETERIORATION OF ETHNOGRAPHIC OBJECTS: IDENTIFICATION, PREVENTION, AND TREATMENT|date=July 18, 2006|publisher=John F. Kennedy University|location=Pleasant Hill, CA|url=http://library2.jfku.edu/Museum_Studies/Glass_Bead_Deterioration.pdf|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref>
==Conservation== In the earliest stage of glass disease, it may be possible to wash the glass to remove the surface alkali. The Corning Museum of Glass recommends washing with tap water (tepid, not hot<ref name="Newton"/>) and a mild (non-ionic<ref name="Newton"/>) conservation detergent. This should be followed by rinsing with de-ionized or distilled water, and careful drying to remove moisture. Careful washing can remove surface deposits, restore the appearance of clearness to the glass, and help to slow further deterioration.<ref name="Washing">{{cite web|title=Washing Glass|url=https://blog.cmog.org/2011/12/09/washing-glass/|website=Corning Museum of Glass|date=December 9, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Newton">{{cite book|first1=Roy|last1=Newton|first2=Sandra|last2=Davison |title=Conservation of glass|date=1996|publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann|location=Oxford|isbn=0750624485|pages=207-209}}</ref> [[Ethanol]] has also been suggested for cleaning, particularly for glass beads, depending on the surrounding materials that may be affected.<ref name="O'Hern"/>
Once more serious damage has occurred, it cannot be reversed. Climate control of humidity and temperature is a possible intervention. Because crizzling results from the reaction of components of the glass with water vapour, controlling humidity and temperature can slow its occurrence.<ref name="Connor"/> At the [[Corning Museum of Glass]], items in the collection are kept at stable levels of relative humidity, between 40 and 55 percent.<ref name="Laidman"/> Fans may be used within a case to encourage the movement of air and minimize adsorption of moisture on the glass surface. Deterioration is more likely to occur in areas with restricted air-flow which allow moisture to remain on the glass.<ref name= "Koob" /> Chemical methods for retarding corrosion rates and stabilizing surfaces are being investigated.<ref name="Hogg"/>
When a composite object contains a variety of materials, one of which is sick glass, the considerations involved in conserving and displaying the object become more complicated. For example, the [[British Museum]] chose to conserve and display a Siberian shamanic apron made of leather, glass and other materials. They weighed the likelihood that it would decay more quickly if shown against the desirability of making a unique object visible and the inevitability of its eventual degradation. "Its conservation and display ensures that access to this beautiful and unique object is maximized before the pale yellow beads, which are intrinsic to the object, are inevitably lost beyond repair."<ref name="Swift">{{cite journal|last1=Swift|first1=Rachel|last2=Meek|first2=Andrew S.|last3=Rode|first3=Nicole|last4=Komlosy|first4=Anouska|title=A radioactive shamanic apron with glass disease|journal=The British Museum Technical Research Bulletin|date=2012|volume=6|pages=25-32|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/pdf/BMTRB_6_Swift-et-al.pdf|accessdate=20 April 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

[[Category:Conservation and restoration]] [[Category:Glass art]] [[Category:Glass chemistry]] [[Category:Glass coating and surface modification]] [[Category:Museology]]

{{Bahá'í sidebar}} The '''Guardian''' is a hereditary office of the [[Bahá'í Faith]] that is first mentioned in the ''[[Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá]]''. [[Shoghi Effendi]] was named as the first Guardian of the Bahá'í Faith, and future Guardians were to be appointed from among the [[Aghsán|male descendants of Bahá'u'lláh]]. However, since Shoghi Effendi died without having named a successor Guardian, no person could be named to fulfill the position after his death on November 4, 1957, and he remains the only individual acknowledged as Guardian of the Bahá'í Faith, but his guidance remains in the written record of his many writings.<ref name="Smith Shoghi Effendi">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter|authorlink= Peter Smith (historian) |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Shoghi Effendi |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 978-1-85168-184-6 |pages= 314–317}}</ref><ref name="Smith Guradianship">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter|authorlink= Peter Smith (historian) |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Guardianship |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 978-1-85168-184-6 |pages= 169–170}}</ref>
==Background== Being `Abdu'l-Bahá's eldest grandson, the first son of `Abdu'l-Bahá's eldest daughter Ḍiyá'iyyih Khánum, Shoghi Effendi had a special relationship with his grandfather. Zia Baghdadi, a contemporary Bahá'í, relates that when Shoghi Effendi was only five years of age, he pestered his grandfather to write a Tablet for him, which `Abdu'l-Bahá obliged.<ref name="five">{{cite book |author = Rabbani, R. |authorlink = Rúhíyyih Khanum | url= http://bahai-library.com/khanum_priceless_pearl | chapter-url= http://bahai-library.com/khanum_priceless_pearl&chapter=1 | year = 1969 |title = The Priceless Pearl |page = 8 | chapter= The Childhood and Youth of Shoghi Effendi | edition = Hardcover |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust: 2000 |location = London, UK |isbn = 978-1-870989-91-6 }}</ref>
`Abdu'l-Bahá's family physician, a German doctor who later became a Bahá'í, would relate that in 1910, when Shoghi Effendi was thirteen years old, `Abdu'l-Bahá named him his successor, referring to him as his "future Elisha."<ref name="thirteen">{{cite book |author = Rabbani, R. |authorlink = Rúhíyyih Khanum | url= http://bahai-library.com/khanum_priceless_pearl | chapter-url= http://bahai-library.com/khanum_priceless_pearl&chapter=1 | year = 1969 |title = The Priceless Pearl |page = 13 | chapter= The Childhood and Youth of Shoghi Effendi | edition = Hardcover |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust: 2000 |location = London, UK |isbn = 978-1-870989-91-6 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Gail| first = Marzieh | title = ‘Abdu’l-Bahá: Portrayals from East and West | journal = World Order | volume = 06 | issue = 01 | pages = 29–41 | date = | year = 1971 | url = http://bahai-library.com/essays/portrayals.html | doi = | id = }}</ref> Shoghi Effendi remained close to his grandfather during his years as a student, first at the [[De La Salle Brothers|LaSallian]] [http://cdf.edu.ps/en/?page_id=182 Collège des Frères] in Haifa and later as a boarder in Beirut, first at a Catholic school and later at the [[Syrian Protestant College]]. Shoghi Effendi was to accompany his grandfather on his [[`Abdu'l-Bahá's journeys to the West|journeys to the West]] but was unable to proceed after port authorities in Naples prevented Shoghi Effendi from continuing due to illness.<ref name="Naples">{{cite book |author = Rabbani, R. |authorlink = Rúhíyyih Khanum | url= http://bahai-library.com/khanum_priceless_pearl | chapter-url= http://bahai-library.com/khanum_priceless_pearl&chapter=1 | year = 1969 |title = The Priceless Pearl |page = 20 | chapter= The Childhood and Youth of Shoghi Effendi | edition = Hardcover |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust: 2000 |location = London, UK |isbn = 978-1-870989-91-6 }}</ref><ref name="Smith AbdulBaha">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter|authorlink= Peter Smith (historian) |encyclopedia= A Concise Encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= 'Abdu'l-Bahá |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 978-1-85168-184-6 |pages= 16–18 | ref = harv }}</ref> At the end of World War I, after he had received his Bachelor of Arts degree in Beirut, Shoghi Effendi spent nearly two years of constant companionship with `Abdu'l-Bahá before proceeding to [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] to further his studies and improve his English.<ref>{{cite book |author = Rabbani, R. |authorlink = Rúhíyyih Khanum | url= http://bahai-library.com/khanum_priceless_pearl | chapter-url= http://bahai-library.com/khanum_priceless_pearl&chapter=1 | year = 1969 |title = The Priceless Pearl |pages = 30–31 | chapter= The Childhood and Youth of Shoghi Effendi | edition = Hardcover |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust: 2000 |location = London, UK |isbn = 978-1-870989-91-6 }}</ref>
At the time of `Abdu'l-Bahá's death in [[Acre, Israel|Acre]] on November 28, 1921, Shoghi Effendi was a twenty-four-year-old student enrolled at [[Balliol College, Oxford]].<ref name="Smith Shoghi Effendi"/><ref>{{cite book |first=Riaz |last=Khadem |year=1999 |title=Shoghi Effendi in Oxford |publisher=George Ronald |location=Oxford, UK |isbn=978-0-85398-423-8 }}</ref> Upon reading the telegram announcing `Abdu'l-Bahá's death, in the home of [[Wellesley Tudor Pole]] who was Secretary of the London Local Spiritual Assembly, Shoghi Effendi passed out.<ref>{{cite web| last = Khanum | first = Rúhíyyih | authorlink = Rúhíyyih Khanum | editor-last = Merrick| editor-first = David | title = Talks / presentations by Bahá'í notables | work = Rúhíyyih Khanum's Tribute to Shoghi Effendi at the Kampala Conference Jan 1958 | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | date = 1958-08-28 | url = http://bahai-library.com/rkhanum_kampala_1958_jan | doi = | accessdate = October 17, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Khanum | first = Rúhíyyih | authorlink = Rúhíyyih Khanum | title = The Guardian of the Baha'i Faith | publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust | year = 1988 | location = 27 Rutland Gate, London | url = http://www.docstoc.com/docs/1264004/The-Guardian-of-the-Bahai-Faith | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-900125-59-4 | page = 13}}</ref> After spending a few days with [[John Esslemont]], Shoghi Effendi left England on December 16, 1921, accompanied by [[Sara Blomfield|Lady Blomfield]] and his sister [[covenant-breaker#Covenant-Breaking in Shoghi Effendi's immediate family|Ruhangiz]], and arrived in Haifa on December 29.<ref>{{cite book |author = Rabbani, R. |authorlink = Rúhíyyih Khanum |year = 1969 |title = The Priceless Pearl | chapter = The Passing of `Abdu'l-Bahá and Its Immediate Consequences | url = http://bahai-library.com/khanum_priceless_pearl&chapter=2 | edition = Hardcover |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust: 2000 |location = London, UK |isbn = 978-1-870989-91-6 | page = 41}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last = Taherzadeh |first = A.|authorlink= Adib Taherzadeh |year = 2000 |title = The Child of the Covenant |publisher = George Ronald |place = Oxford, UK |isbn = 978-0-85398-439-9 | pages = 272–273}}</ref> `Abdu'l-Bahá's ''[[Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá|Will and Testament]]'', addressed to Shoghi Effendi, was read a few days after Shoghi Effendi's arrival in Haifa.<ref>{{cite book |author = Rabbani, R. |authorlink = Rúhíyyih Khanum |year = 1969 |title = The Priceless Pearl | chapter = The Passing of `Abdu'l-Bahá and Its Immediate Consequences | url = http://bahai-library.com/khanum_priceless_pearl&chapter=2 | edition = Hardcover |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust: 2000 |location = London, UK |isbn = 978-1-870989-91-6 | page = 44}}</ref>
==Will and Testament of ‘Abdu’l-Bahá== The ''[[Will and Testament of ‘Abdu’l-Bahá]]'' was written by ‘Abdu’l-Bahá on three different occasions, and the text remains in three parts.<ref name="Smith Will and Testament">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter|authorlink= Peter Smith (historian) |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 1-85168-184-1 |pages= 356–357}}</ref><ref name="‘Abdu’l-Bahá Will and Testament">{{cite book |author=‘Abdu’l-Bahá |authorlink=‘Abdu’l-Bahá |origyear=1901-08 |year=1990 |title=The Will And Testament of ‘Abdu’l-Bahá |publisher= Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location= |isbn= 978-0877433736 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/WT/}}</ref> In his ''Will'' ‘Abdu’l-Bahá addresses the Bahá'í Covenant and the role of [[Mírzá Muhammad `Alí]] as a [[Covenant-breaker]]; outlines the obligation and responsibilities of the [[Hands of the Cause of God]]; explains the election of the [[Universal House of Justice]]; and defines the institution of the Guardianship as a hereditary office with its essential function as Interpreter of the Bahá'í writings.<ref name="Smith Will and Testament"/><ref name="‘Abdu’l-Bahá Will and Testament"/> Shoghi Effendi describes the ''Will'', along with the ''[[Kitáb-i-Aqdas]],'' the ''[[Tablets of the Divine Plan]],'' and the ''[[Tablet of Carmel]]'', as one of the charters of the [[Bahá'í administration|Bahá'í Administrative Order]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Effendi |first=Shoghi |date= |title=Messages to the Bahá’í World: 1950–1957| url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/MBW/ |chapter=Achievements of Second Year of Ten Year Plan |chapter-url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/MBW/mbw-45.html#pg84| page=85 |location= |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |isbn=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Shoghi |last=Effendi |authorlink=Shoghi Effendi |year=1944 | page = 214 | chapter=Chapter XII: Bahá’u’lláh’s Incarceration in ‘Akká (Continued)|title=God Passes By |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn=0-87743-020-9 |chapter-url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/GPB/gpb-13.html#pg213 | url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/GPB/ }}</ref>
`Abdu'l-Bahá's will provided a framework for the Guardian within the [[Bahá'í administration]] including:
*`A requirement that the Guardian appoint his successor "in his own life-time ... that differences may not arise after his [the Guardian's] passing."<ref name="ency_guardianship">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|pp=169–170}}</ref> The appointee was required to be either the first-born son of the Guardian, or one of the [[Aghsán]] (literally: Branches; male descendants of Bahá'u'lláh).<ref name="ency_guardianship"/> Finally, `Abdu'l-Bahá left a responsibility to [[Custodians|nine Hands of the Cause]], elected from all of the Hands, who "whether unanimously or by a majority vote, must give their assent to the choice of the one whom the Guardian of the Cause of God hath chosen as his successor."<ref name="ency_hands">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|pp=175–177}}</ref> *`Abdu'l-Bahá's will also stated that the [[Hands of the Cause]] were to be nominated and appointed by the Guardian and are to be under his direction and obey his command.<ref name="ency_hands"/> *The Guardian is to be the head of the [[Universal House of Justice]] and either attend its deliberations in person or appoint a representative to do so.<ref name="Will 14-15">{{cite book |author=‘Abdu’l-Bahá |authorlink=‘Abdu’l-Bahá |origyear=1901-08 |year=1990 |title=The Will And Testament of ‘Abdu’l-Bahá |publisher= Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA| chapter= Part One| pages=14–15 | chapter-url= http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/WT/wt-1.html#pg14 | isbn= 978-0877433736 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/WT/}}</ref> *`Abdu'l-Bahá's will stipulates that [[Huqúqu'lláh]], which had been made directly to Bahá'u'lláh and `Abdu'l-Bahá during their lifetimes, would henceforth be made to the Guardian.<ref name="Smith Covenant">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter|authorlink= Peter Smith (historian) |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Covenant |year= 2000 |publisher= Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 1-85168-184-1 |pages= 114–5}}</ref>
===Appointing Shoghi Effendi as Guardian=== Although in the [[Tablets of Bahá'u'lláh#Kitáb-i-`Ahd (Book of the Covenant)|''Kitáb-i-‘Ahd'']] Bahá'u'lláh designates [[Mírzá Muhammad `Alí]] as `Abdu'l-Bahá's successor,<ref>{{cite book |author=Bahá'u'lláh |authorlink=Bahá'u'lláh |origyear=1873-92 |year=1994 |title=Tablets of Bahá'u'lláh Revealed After the Kitáb-i-Aqdas |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn=0-87743-174-4 |chapter= Kitáb-i-`Ahd (Book of the Covenant) |chapter-url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/TB/tb-16.html#pg222 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/TB/ | page=223 |ref=harv }}</ref> in his ''Will,'' `Abdu'l-Bahá reprimands his brother as "The Center of Sedition, the Prime Mover of mischief"<ref name="Will 9">{{cite book |author=‘Abdu’l-Bahá |authorlink=‘Abdu’l-Bahá |origyear=1901-08 |year=1990 |title=The Will And Testament of ‘Abdu’l-Bahá |publisher= Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA| chapter= Part One| chapter-url= http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/WT/wt-1.html#pg9| page=9| isbn= 978-0877433736 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/WT/}}</ref> and establishes the institution of the Guardianship, appointing Shoghi Effendi to this newly created office:<ref name="Smith Shoghi Effendi"/><ref name="Smith Guradianship"/>
==Shoghi Effendi writings on the Institution of the Guardianship == As Guardian, Shoghi Effendi held a new and distinct role. Building on the foundation that had been established in ‘Abdu’l-Bahá's will, Shoghi Effendi elaborated on the role of the Guardian in the developing [[Bahá'í administration|Bahá'í Administrative Order]] in several works, including ''[[Bahá'í Administration (book)|Bahá'í Administration]]'' and the ''[[World Order of Bahá'u'lláh]],'' in the chapter entitled ''The Administrative Order.''<ref name="Smith Shoghi Effendi"/><ref name="Smith Guradianship"/><ref name="Shoghi Effendi, Writings of ">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter|authorlink= Peter Smith (historian) |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Shoghi Effendi, Writings of |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 978-1-85168-184-6 |pages= 317–318}}</ref>
In those works, Shoghi Effendi goes to great lengths to emphasize that the Guardianship is a distinct station from that of [[Manifestation of God|Manifestation]] or Center of the [[Covenant of Bahá'u'lláh|Covenant]]:<ref name="Smith Shoghi Effendi"/><ref name="Smith Guradianship"/><ref name="Shoghi Effendi, Writings of "/> Shoghi Effendi also was critical of Bahá'ís referring to him as a holy personage, asking them not to celebrate his birthday or have his picture on display.<ref name="Shoghi Effendi, Writings of "/> Furthermore, he did not refer to his own personal role as an individual, but instead to the institution of the Guardianship.<ref name="Smith Shoghi Effendi"/><ref name="Smith Guradianship"/> In his correspondences, Shoghi Effendi signed his letters to Bahá'ís as "brother" and "co-worker," to the extent that even when addressing youth, he referred to himself as "Your True Brother."<ref>{{cite book |last= Effendi |first= Shoghi |date= April 1, 1991 |title= Your True Brother: Messages to Junior Youth Written |url= http://bahai-library.com/shoghieffendi_your_true_brother |location= |publisher= George Ronald |page= |isbn= 978-0853983248}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first = Shoghi |last = Effendi |year = 1974 |title = Bahá'í Administration | page= |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 978-0-87743-166-4 |url = http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/BA/}}</ref> Instead, Shoghi Effendi goes to great lengths to emphasize the significance of the "Institution of Guardianship," which he calls the "head cornerstone of the [[Bahá'í administration|Administrative Order]] of the Cause of Bahá’u’lláh,"<ref name="MA 21">{{cite book |last=Effendi |first=Shoghi |date=1947 |title=Messages to America: Selected Letters and Cablegrams Addressed to the Baha'i of North America 1932-1946 |url= http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/MA/ |location= |publisher=Baha'i Publishing Committee |page=8 |chapter-url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/MA/ma-21.html | chapter= Institution of Guardianship Now Further Reinforced |isbn=}}</ref>
In his writings, Shoghi Effendi delineates a distinct separation of powers between the "twin pillars that support this mighty Administrative Structure—the institutions of the Guardianship and of the Universal House of Justice."<ref name="Shoghi WOB 148">{{cite book |first=Shoghi |last=Effendi |authorlink= Shoghi Effendi |year=1938 |title=The World Order of Bahá’u’lláh |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn=0-87743-231-7 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/WOB/index.html| chapter=The Administrative Order| page=148| chapter-url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/WOB/wob-40.html#pg148 }}</ref>
==Rights of the Guardian== *Interpreter of the Bahá'í writing : As Guardian, Shoghi Effendi was the "Interpreter of the Word of God,"<ref name="Will 11">{{cite book |author=‘Abdu’l-Bahá |authorlink=‘Abdu’l-Bahá |origyear=1901-08 |year=1990 |title=The Will And Testament of ‘Abdu’l-Bahá |publisher= Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA| chapter= Part One| page=11| chapter-url= http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/WT/wt-1.html#pg11 | isbn= 978-0877433736 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/WT/}}</ref> "with the right and obligation to interpret the Bahá’í teachings."<ref name="Shoghi WOB 151">{{cite book |first=Shoghi |last=Effendi |authorlink= Shoghi Effendi |year=1938 |title=The World Order of Bahá’u’lláh |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn=0-87743-231-7 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/WOB/index.html| page=151 | chapter=The Administrative Order| chapter-url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/WOB/wob-40.html#pg151 }}</ref> His interpretations of the writings of Bahá'u'lláh and `Abdu'l-Bahá were authoritative and binding.<ref name="Shoghi Effendi, Writings of "/><ref>{{cite book| last = Smith | first = Peter|authorlink= Peter Smith (historian) | year = 2008 | title = An Introduction to the Baha'i Faith | publisher = Cambridge University Press | place = Cambridge | isbn=0-521-86251-5 | ref = harv |pages = 55–56, 102–103}}</ref> *Expulsion and excommunication : The Guardian has the power to declare Bahá'ís who cause disunity in the Faith as [[Covenant-breakers]]:<ref name="Smith Shoghi Effendi"/><ref name="Smith Guradianship"/><ref name="Smith Covenant"/>
==After Shoghi Effendi== Although the [[Kitáb-i-Aqdas]] requires every Bahá'í to have a [[Will and testament|will]],<ref>{{cite book |author = Bahá'u'lláh |authorlink = Bahá'u'lláh |orig-year= 1873| year=1992 |title = The Kitáb-i-Aqdas: The Most Holy Book |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust| location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 978-0853989998|chapter= Paragraph 109 |chapter-url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-6.html#pg59 |url = http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Universal House of Justice |first= |date=2000 |title=Messages from The Universal House of Justice, 1986-2001 |url=http://bahai-library.com/uhj_messages_1986_2001| chapter= Clarification on Bahá’í Wills | chapter-url=http://bahai-library.com/uhj_messages_1986_2001#Clarification_on_Bahá’í_Wills | |location= Wilmette, Illinois, USA |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |page=229 |isbn= 978-0877433569}}</ref> Shoghi Effendi did not have one when he died unexpectedly of [[Asian Flu]] on November 4, 1957 in London, England.<ref name="Smith Shoghi Effendi"/><ref name="Smith Guradianship"/> Shoghi Effendi did not have any children and had not designated a successor Guardian. With [[Munirih Khánum#Family|all living male descendants of Bahá'u'lláh having been declared Covenant-breakers]] by either `Abdu'l-Bahá or Shoghi Effendi, no suitable qualifying candidates remained for appointment to the office of Guardian.<ref name="Smith Shoghi Effendi"/><ref name="Smith Guradianship"/><ref name="Smith Custodians">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter|authorlink= Peter Smith (historian) |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Custodians |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 978-1-85168-184-6 |page= 117}}</ref>
On November 19, 1957, nine of the [[Hands of the Cause]] issued an "Official Statement" after searching through Shogi Effendi's personal affects in Haifa, Israel, affirming that "the safe and desk have been opened and searched and the non existence of a Will and Testament executed by Shoghi Effendi was definitely established."<ref>{{cite book |author = Rabbani, R. |authorlink = Rúhíyyih Khanum | url= http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians | year = 1992 |title = Ministry of the Custodians: An Account of the Stewardship of the Hands of the Cause 1957-1963| chapter-url=http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians&chapter=1#27 | chapter= Official Statement| page=27 |edition = Hardcover |publisher = Baha'i World Centre |location = Haifa |isbn = 978-0853983507 }}</ref> A subsequent "Unanimous Proclamation of the 27 [[Hands of the Cause of God]]" on November 25 confirmed that Shoghi Effendi had died "without having appointed his successor."<ref>{{cite book |author = Rabbani, R. |authorlink = Rúhíyyih Khanum | url= http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians | year = 1992 |title = Ministry of the Custodians: An Account of the Stewardship of the Hands of the Cause 1957-1963| chapter-url=http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians&chapter=1#28 | page=28 | chapter= Unanimous Proclamation of the 27 Hands of the Cause of God | edition = Hardcover |publisher = Baha'i World Centre |location = Haifa |isbn = 978-0853983507 }}</ref> The Hands of the Cause unanimously voted it was impossible to legitimately recognize and assent to a successor.<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.e">{{Harvnb|Momen|2003|loc=§G.2.e}} [http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_covenant#5.%20Dealing%20with%20Covenant-breaking.]</ref> The Bahá'í community was in a situation not dealt with explicitly in the provisions of the Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá.<ref name="ency_guardianship"/> Furthermore, the [[Universal House of Justice]] had not yet been elected, which represented the only Bahá'í institution authorized to adjudicate on matters not covered by the religion's three central figures.<ref name="ency_hands"/>
The Hands of the Cause of God elected from among their own nine individuals who would serve as [[Custodians]] to help lead the transition of the [[International Bahá'í Council]], whose members had previously been appointed by Shoghi Effendi, into the Universal House of Justice, whose members are elected by all the members of each Bahá'í [[National Spiritual Assembly]] in the world.<ref>{{cite book |author = Rabbani, R. |authorlink = Rúhíyyih Khanum | url= http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians | year = 1992 |title = Ministry of the Custodians: An Account of the Stewardship of the Hands of the Cause 1957-1963| chapter-url= http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians&chapter=1#34 | chapter= Resolution of the Hands of Cause of God | page=34 | edition = Hardcover |publisher = Baha'i World Centre |location = Haifa |isbn = 978-0853983507 }}</ref>
On April 8, 1960, [[Mason Remey]] one of the Hands of the Cause and president of the [[International Bahá'í Council]], issued a written announcement claiming that he was the second Guardian of the Bahá'í Faith. He based his claim on the idea that by appointing him as President of the International Bahá'í Council, the embryonic form of the Universal House of Justice which would be led by the Guardian, Shoghi Effendi had in fact implicitly named him as the second Guardian.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter|authorlink= Peter Smith (historian) |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 978-1-85168-184-6 |page= 292}}</ref> Mason Remey's claim was largely rejected with several notable exceptions, including five members of the National Spiritual Assembly of France led by Joel Marangella. The remaining 26 Hands of the Cause unanimously declared Remey and whoever followed him Covenant-breakers.
The Universal House of Justice later announced that it could not legislate to make possible the appointment of a successor Guardian to Shoghi Effendi.<ref>{{cite book | editor1-last= Marks |editor1-first= Geoffry W. |last=Universal House of Justice |first= |date= 1996 |title= Messages from the Universal House of Justice 1963-86 |url= http://bahai-library.com/uhj_messages_1963-86_full&chapter=2#14 |location= |publisher= Baha'i Publishing Trust |page= 14 |isbn= 978-0877432395}}</ref> The Universal House of Justice also determined that it could not appoint any further [[Hands of the Cause]], whose work is now carried out by other [[Bahá'í administration#Appointed institutions|appointed institutions]] such as the [[Continental Counsellors]] and the [[Bahá'í administration#Auxiliary Boards|Auxiliary Boards]].

{{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Use South African English|date=January 2013}} '''''Gundwana v Steko Development and Others'''''2011 (3) SA 608 (CC). is an important case in [[South Africa]]n [[South African property law|property]] [[South African law|law]], heard before the [[Constitutional Court of South Africa|Constitutional Court]]Moseneke DCJ, Cameron J, Froneman J, Jafta J, Khampepe J, Mogoeng J, Nkabinde J, Van Der Westhuizen J, Yacoob J and Mthiyane AJ. on 10 February 2011. == Facts == Elsie Gundwana bought a home through a loan provided by the bank, securing her debt by a mortgage bond on the property. When subsequently she fell into arrears, the bank obtained, by default judgement, an order declaring her property to be executable. The property was accordingly sold four years later. An order for eviction was sought against Ms Gundwana, and the matter ended up at the Constitutional Court. == Issue == Gundwana sought orders that the registrar, acting under the Uniform Rules of Court,s 31(5). could not grant an order declaring a mortgaged home to be executable. == Judgment == The court held that the registrar's order, under section 31(5) of the Uniform Rules of Court, declaring residential property to be executable, was unconstitutional, because judicial oversight is required where execution is sought against indigent debtors. == Consequences == The Uniform Rules of Court now contains an amendment46(1). dealing with the consequences of this judgment:
(1)(a) No writ of execution against the immovable property of any judgment debtor shall issue until— :(i) a return shall have been made of any process which may have been issued against the movable property of the judgment debtor from which it appears that the said person has not sufficient movable property to satisfy the writ; or :(ii) such immovable property shall have been declared to be specially executable by the court or, in the case of a judgment granted in terms of rule 31(5), by the registrar: Provided that, where the property sought to be attached is the primary residence of the judgment debtor, no writ shall issue unless the court, having considered all the relevant circumstances, orders execution against such property.
== See also == * ''[[Jaftha v Schoeman]]'' * [[South African property law]] * ''[[Standard Bank v Saunderson]]'' == References == * ''Gundwana v Steko Development and Others'' [http://www.saflii.org/za/cases/ZACC/2011/14.html 2011 (3) SA 608 (CC)]. == Notes == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Constitutional Court of South Africa cases]] [[Category:2011 in South African law]] [[Category:2011 in case law]] [[Category:South African property case law]] {{SouthAfrica-case-law-stub}}

{{Infobox website | name = Hamichlol | screenshot = | screenshot_size = | logo = | logo_size = | caption = | url = [http://www.hamichlol.org.il hamichlol.org.il] | commercial = No | location = | type = [[censored]] [[wiki]]-based [[Internet encyclopedia project]] for the Torah-observant public | language = [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] | registration = You must register to edit articles | owner = Institute for Literacy and Proper Knowledge | launch date = {{start date and age|2015|1|11}} | alexa = 1,359 in Israel ({{as of|2018|August|9|alt=August 2018}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web |url = https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/hamichlol.org.il |title = Hamichlol.org.il Site Info |publisher = [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate = August 9, 2018 }}</ref> }} '''Hamichlol''' ({{lang-he-n|המכלול}} "The Entirety") is a [[censored]] [[wiki]]-based [[Internet encyclopedia project]] for the [[:he:שומר תורה ומצוות|Torah-observant public]] (ציבור שומר תורה ומצוות). The site is managed and operated by the Institute for Literacy and Proper Knowledge, which was established for the purpose of creating the site. The articles mainly censor any mentioning of [[homosexuality]], information that contradicts a [[Creationism|creationist]] worldview, and other behaviors deemed [[Tzniut|immodest]].<ref>[http://www.hamichlol.org.il/%D7%94%D7%9E%D7%9B%D7%9C%D7%95%D7%9C:%D7%A1%D7%99%D7%A0%D7%95%D7%9F/%D7%9E%D7%93%D7%99%D7%A0%D7%99%D7%95%D7%AA_%D7%94%D7%A1%D7%99%D7%A0%D7%95%D7%9F]</ref> The site is referred to by the site owners as an ''aspeklaria'' ({{lang-he-n|אספקלריה}}), which means in [[Latin]] "mirror", as it is a re-edited edition of the Hebrew Wikipedia.
The site was launched on January 11, 2015. As of August 9, 2018 the site contained 111,466 articles for a total approximating half the number of articles found on the [[Hebrew Wikipedia]].
As of August 9, 2018, the site's [[Alexa Internet|Alexa]]'s ranking was 1,359 in Israel.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/hamichlol.org.il |title=Hamichlol.org.il Traffic, Demographics and Competitors |publisher=Alexa |date= |accessdate=2018-08-10}}</ref>
==Background== In 2014 the Israeli [[Hasidic]] rabbi Yosef Kaminer founded the Institute for Literacy and Proper Knowledge ({{lang-he-n|המכון לאוריינות וידע כהלכה}}) through which the site would be produced.<ref>{{citation|date = December 10, 2017|url = http://m.ch10.co.il/news/409776/#.WpssmXOIZ-F|title = Rabbi Yosef Kaminer presents 'the Haredi Wikipedia'|author = Nochi Gold|access-date = March 3, 2018|publisher = m.ch10.co.il }}</ref> According to the site owners the site is intended to be used by the [[:he:ציבור שומר תורה|Torah-observant public]] (ציבור שומר תורה ומצוות), and especially by the ''[[Haredi]]'' (Ultra-Orthodox Jewry) whom are very conservative and refrain from using Wikipedia's content according to their stringent interpretations of ''[[halakha]]''. Hamichlol aspires to be "the largest Jewish encyclopedia in history, which includes articles on all issues pertaining to the Torah, Jewish values and the history of the Jewish people, but also knowledge pertaining to mankind and from all the secular" ({{lang-he-n|חולין}} [transliteration: ''hulin'']) "fields–written in clean language according to the Jewish worldview."{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}
==Kosher considerations== In order to create the site's foundation, the creators of the site chose, as part of the initial development of the site, to import the entire [[Hebrew Wikipedia]] and re-edit or delete the content which is not proper for the Torah-observant public, and specifically the [[ultra-Orthodox]] readers. The content is imported from the Hebrew Wikipedia in accordance with Wikipedia's free license, which enables editors to perform such a "[[Fork (software development)|split]]". Since much of the existing content is copied from Wikipedia and re-edited it is easy to find information which was omitted by comparing specific articles on the site with the parallel articles at the Hebrew Wikipedia. Examples of such differences include:
* In the '''[[Biology]]''' article<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hamichlol.org.il/%D7%91%D7%99%D7%95%D7%9C%D7%95%D7%92%D7%99%D7%94 |title=ביולוגיה – המכלול |language= |publisher=Hamichlol.org.il |date=2001-01-30 |accessdate=2018-08-10}}</ref>, which was initially copied entirely from the Hebrew Wikipedia and then re-edited, the "Evolution" ({{lang-he-n|אבולוציה}}) section was re-named to "The Order of the Creation of Creatures" ({{lang-he-n|סדר הבריאה של היצורים}}) and the content of this section was changed so that instead of saying that all organisms on the Earth have descended from a common ancestor, it was changed to say that all forms of life were created in the [[Genesis creation narrative|Six Days of Genesis]]. * In the '''[[Beit Zeit]]''' article<ref>{{cite web|url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:-9zVYJ4CwrsJ:www.hamichlol.org.il/%25D7%2591%25D7%2599%25D7%25AA_%25D7%2596%25D7%2599%25D7%25AA+&cd=1&hl=no&ct=clnk&gl=no |title=בית זית – המכלול |publisher=Webcache.googleusercontent.com |date= |accessdate=2018-08-10}}</ref>, which was initially copied entirely from the Hebrew Wikipedia and then re-edited, the mentioning of the "[[Beit Zeit#Dinosaur Footprints|Dinosaur Footprints]]" site in Israel was omitted as it is a site which contains a layer of ancient rock that contains some 200 traces of dinosaur tracks from tens of millions of years ago. Other articles and references on the site which present dates or periods that contradict the age of the world according to the Torah are removed from all the articles imported from the Hebrew Wikipedia.<ref>[http://www.hamichlol.org.il/המכלול:סינון/מדיניות_הסינון]</ref> * In the article about '''[[The Holocaust]]'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hamichlol.org.il/%D7%94%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%90%D7%94 |title=השואה – המכלול |language= |publisher=Hamichlol.org.il |date= |accessdate=2018-08-10}}</ref>, which was copied entirely from the Hebrew Wikipedia and then re-edited, the mentioning in the intro that [[homosexuals]] were also murdered by Nazi Germany in World War II was completely removed. Other articles and references on the site to homosexuality or homosexuals are removed from all articles imported from the Hebrew Wikipedia. * Because many [[Haredi]] avoid '''pictures of [[women]]''', any pictures on the site that include women, such as historical pictures or group photos inclusive of men and women (for example, a photo of the [[Thirty-fourth government of Israel#Cabinet members|thirty-fourth government of Israel's cabinet]]) are [[photoshopped]] to remove women.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-ultra-orthodox-wikipedia-is-literally-rewriting-history-1.5866754|title=Without Women or Evolution: 'Ultra-Orthodox Wikipedia' Is Literally Rewriting History|first=Omer|last=Benjakob|date=1 March 2018|publisher=|via=Haaretz}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hamichlol.org.il/%D7%94%D7%9E%D7%9B%D7%9C%D7%95%D7%9C:%D7%90%D7%95%D7%93%D7%95%D7%AA |title=המכלול:אודות – המכלול |language={{he icon}} |publisher=Hamichlol.org.il |date= |accessdate=2018-08-09}}</ref> In other instances, with articles about prominent historical female figures the portraits of the women are replaced with pictures of their graves.
As of August 25, 2018, out of the 121,929 articles imported from Wikipedia, 22,791 of the imported articles currently are not accessible to the readers as long as the editorial team hasn't yet produced a censored and/or re-edited versions of these articles. The owners of the website explicitly state that in the instances in which imported articles from Wikipedia contain content deemed "problematic", the editorial team of the website will gradually review all of these articles and determine whether the content is appropriate - problematic articles with proper content will be rewritten while problematic articles with inappropriate content will eventually be permanently deleted. As of August 25, 2018 of all temporarily blocked imported articles awaiting to be reviewed, some of the articles that are most sought-after at the Hebrew Wikipedia include: [[YouTube]], [[Gal Gadot]], [[Ten Commandments]], [[Eyal Golan]], [[Harry Potter]], [[Ofra Haza]], [[Sigmund Freud]], [[Christianity]], [[Independence Day (Israel)]], [[Judaism]], [[New Testament]], [[Sports]], [[Racism]], [[Academy Awards]], [[Human evolution]], [[Woman]], [[Status quo (Israel)]] [[Age of Enlightenment]], [[Breast cancer]], [[Tower of Babel]], [[Muslims]] , [[The Simpsons]], [[Apocalypse]], [[Hell]], [[Table tennis]], [[Homo]], [[Platonic love]], [[Sport in Israel]], [[Bourekas film]], [[Handball]], [[Race (human categorization)]], [[Jewish and democratic state]], [[Maccabiah Games]], [[Catholic Church]], [[Satire]], [[Paganism]], [[Samaritanism]].
== Copyrights == All content on the site which was originally imported from Wikipedia is provided under the free license [[CC-BY-SA]]. The copyrights of all the rest of the site's content is reserved to the Institute for Literacy and Proper Knowledge.

{{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=June 2007}} {{Tone|date=March 2016}} }}
[[File:James Campbell - News from My Lad - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|''News from My Lad'' by [[James Campbell (artist)|James Campbell]], 1858-1859 ([[Walker Art Gallery]])]] A '''letter''' is one person's [[written]] [[message]] to another pertaining to some matter of common concern.<ref name=":0" /> Letters have several different types: Formal letters and informal letters. Letters contribute to the protection and conservation of literacy.<ref name=":0">{{cite book |last1=Blake |first1=Gary |author-link1=Gary Blake |last2=Bly |first2=Robert W. |author-link2=Robert W. Bly |title=The Elements of Technical Writing |publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers (United AlStates)|Macmillan Publishers]] |date=1993 |isbn=0020130856 |page=125}}</ref> Letters have been sent since [[Ancient history|antiquity]] and are mentioned in the ''[[Iliad]]''.<ref>Homer, ''Iliad'', 6. 167–70.</ref> Both [[Herodotus]] and [[Thucydides]] mention letters in their histories.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |last=Ebbeler |first=J. |title=Tradition, Innovation, and Epistolary Mores |editor-last=Rousseau |editor-first=P. |work=A Companion to Late Antiquity |date=2009 |publisher=Wiley-Blackwell |location=Chichester |isbn=978-1-4051-1980-1 |page=270}}</ref>
==History of letter writing== [[Image:Einstein Szilard p1.jpg|thumb|The famous [[Einstein letter]] from [[Edward Teller]] and [[Leó Szilárd]] to US President [[Franklin Roosevelt]] suggesting an [[atomic bomb]] project. [[:Image:Einstein Szilard p2.jpg|Click here for page 2.]]]] [[Image:Kate Hepburn Letter.jpg|thumb|A thank-you letter from [[Katharine Hepburn]] to [[Alan Light]] thanking him for his condolences in regards of [[Cary Grant]]'s death]] {{expand section|date=December 2013}} Historically, letters have existed from the time of [[History of India|ancient India]], [[ancient Egypt]] and [[Sumer]], through [[ancient Rome|Rome]], [[ancient Greece|Greece]] and [[History of China#Ancient China|China]], up to the present day. During the seventeenth and eighteenth century, letters were used to self-educate. Letters were a way to practice critical reading, self-expressive writing, polemical writing and also exchange ideas with like-minded others. For some people, letters were seen as a written performance. For others, it was not only seen as a performance but also as a way of communication and a method of gaining feedback. Letters make up several of the books of the [[Bible]]. [[Archives]] of correspondence, whether for personal, diplomatic, or business reasons, serve as [[primary source]]s for [[historian]]s. At certain times, the writing of letters was thought to be an art form and a [[genre]] of [[literature]], for instance in Byzantine [[epistolography]].<ref name=Oxf>"Epistolography" in ''[[Oxford Dictionary of Byzantium|The Oxford Dictionary of Byzantium]]'', [[Oxford University Press]], New York & Oxford, 1991, p. 718. {{ISBN|0195046528}}</ref>
In the ancient world letters were written on a various different materials, including metal, lead, wax-coated wooden tablets, pottery fragments, animal skin, and papyrus. From [[Ovid]], we learn that [[Acontius]] used an apple for his letter to [[Cydippe]].<ref>Ovid, ''Her''. 20</ref>
As [[communication technology]] has diversified, posted letters have become less important as a routine form of communication. For example, the development of the [[telegraph]] drastically shortened the time taken to send a communication, by sending it between distant points as an electrical signal. At the telegraph office closest to the destination, the signal was converted back into writing on paper and delivered to the recipient. The next step was the [[telex]] which avoided the need for local delivery. Then followed the [[fax]] (facsimile) machine: a letter could be transferred electrically from the sender to the receiver through the telephone network as an image. Today, the [[internet]], by means of [[email]], plays a large part in written communications; however, these email communications are not generally referred to as letters but rather as e-mail (or email) messages, messages or simply emails or e-mails, with only the term "letter" generally being reserved for communications on paper.
==The study of letter writing== Due to the timelessness and universality of letter writing, there is a wealth of letters and instructional materials (for example, [[Style guide|manuals]], as in the medieval [[ars dictaminis]]) on letter writing throughout history. The study of letter writing usually involves both the study of [[rhetoric]] and [[grammar]].<ref>Carol Poster and Linda C. Mitchell, eds., ''Letter-Writing Manuals and Instruction from Antiquity to the Present'' (Columbia, SC: U of South Carolina Press, 2007).</ref>
==Advantages of letters== [[File:François Boucher - The Secret Message.jpg|thumbnail|[[François Boucher]] - ''The Secret Message'', 1767 ([[Herzog Anton Ulrich Museum]])]]
Letters are a way to connect with someone not through the internet. Despite email, letters are still popular, particularly in business and for official communications. Letters have the following advantages over email: *No special device is needed to receive a letter, just a postal address, and the letter can be read immediately on receipt. *An advertising mailing can reach every address in a particular area. *A letter provides immediate, and in principle permanent, physical record of communication, without the need for printing. Letters, especially those with a signature and/or on an organization's own notepaper, are more difficult to falsify than is an email and thus provide much better evidence of the contents of the communication. *A letter in the sender's own handwriting is more personal than an email. *If required, small physical objects can be enclosed in the envelope with the letter. *Letters are unable to transmit [[malware]] or other harmful files that can be transmitted by email. *Letter writing leads to the mastery of the technique of good writing. *Letter writing can provide an extension of the face-to-face therapeutic encounter.
==The letter delivery process==
Here is how a letter gets from the sender to the recipient: # Sender writes letter and places it in an [[envelope]] on which the recipient's address is written in the centre front of the envelope. Sender ensures that the recipient's address includes the Zip or Postal Code (if applicable) and often includes his/her return address on the envelope. # Sender buys a [[postage stamp]] and attaches it to the front of the [[envelope]] on the top right corner on the front of the envelope. (For large amount mailings, postage stamps are not used: a [[franking machine]] or other methods are used to pay for postage.) # Sender puts the letter in a postbox. # The national postal service of the sender's country (e.g. [[Royal Mail]], [[United Kingdom|UK]]; [[US Postal Service]], [[United States|US]]; [[Australia Post]] in [[Australia]]; or [[Canada Post]] in [[Canada]]) empties the postbox and takes all the contents to the regional sorting office. # The sorting office then sorts each letter by address and postcode and delivers the letters destined for a particular area to that area's [[post office]]. Letters addressed to a different region are sent to that region's sorting office, to be sorted further. # The local post office dispatches the letters to their delivery personnel who deliver them to the proper addresses.
This whole process, depending on how far the sender is from the recipient, can take anywhere from a day to 3–4 weeks. International mail is sent via [[trains]] and [[airplane]]s to other countries.
However, in 2008, Janet Barrett from the UK, received a RSVP to a party invitation addressed to 'Percy Bateman', from 'Buffy', originally posted on 29 November 1919. It had taken 89 years to be delivered by the Royal Mail.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Guinness Book of World Records 2014|last=Glenday|first=Craig|publisher=|year=2013|isbn=978-1-908843-15-9|location=|pages=127|quote=|via=}}</ref> However, Royal Mail denied this, saying that it would be impossible for a letter to have remained in their system for so long, as checks are carried out regularly. Instead, the letter dated 1919 may have "been a collector's item which was being sent in another envelope and somehow came free of the outer packaging".<ref name="tele1">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/3683828/Royal-Mail-delivers-letter-89-years-late.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170413195911/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/3683828/Royal-Mail-delivers-letter-89-years-late.html|archivedate=13 April 2017|date=8 December 2008|accessdate=13 April 2017|title=Royal Mail delivers letter 89 years late|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}}</ref>
==Types of letter== There are a number of different types of letter: {{div col}} *[[Audio letter]] *[[Business letter]] *[[Cease and desist|Cease and desist letter]] *[[Chain letter]] *[[Cover letter]] *[[Crossed letter]] *[[Dear John letter]] *[[Epistle]] *[[Form letter]] *[[Hate mail]] *[[Hybrid mail]] (semi-electronic delivery) *[[Informal letter]] *[[Letter of credence]] *[[Letter of credit]] *[[Letter of intent]] *[[Letter of introduction]] *[[Letter of marque]] *[[Letter of resignation]] *[[Letter of thanks]] *[[Letter to the editor]] *[[Letters patent]] *[[Love letter]] *[[National Letter of Intent]] *[[Open letter]] *[[Poison pen letter]] *[[Query letter]] *[[Recommendation letter]] and the closely related [[employment reference letter]] *[[Sales letter]] {{div col end}}
==Gallery== <gallery mode="packed"> File:From Caroline Weston to Deborah Weston; Tuesday, June 1, 1841? p1.jpg|By [[Crossed letter|writing both across and down]], the sender of a letter could save on postage. File:Cesare Borgia, handwritten letter 1.jpg|A hand-written letter of [[Cesare Borgia]]. File:Wish list.jpg|A child's letter to [[Santa Claus]]. File:Letter from Arthur Conan Doyle to Herbert Greenhough Smith.jpg|A letter from [[Arthur Conan Doyle]] about ''[[The Hound of the Baskervilles]]''. File:Invitation to Space Needle groundbreaking, 1961.jpg|An invitation letter to the ground-breaking of the Seattle [[Space Needle]], 1961. File:Letter of Resignation of Richard M. Nixon, 1974.jpg|The resignation letter of [[Richard Nixon]], 1974. File:Augusto Tominz - The Letter, 1873.jpg|A [[letter sheet]]. {{Interlanguage link multi|Augusto Tominz|de}} - ''The Letter'', 1873 </gallery>
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Address (geography)|Address]] *[[Avis de réception]] *[[Envelope]] *[[Letter box]] *[[Mail]] *[[Manuscript]] *[[Message in a bottle]] *[[Pen pal]] *[[Proof of delivery]] *[[Return receipt]] *[[salutation (greeting)|Salutation]] *[[Secrecy of letters]] *[[Snail mail]] *[[Valediction]] {{div col end}}
